reviews.review_msg: Prof Labrecque is great, he truly cares about his students. He not only explains things clearly (he does his best), but hell go out of his way to make sure his students really understand. He is available and replies to email quickly. And overall he is a great guy !

Intelligent, fair and helpful professor who takes an interest in his students. Classes are challenging for some if you don't have background in the course but if you make an effort you will shine bright at the end.

Super nice guy, less than great prof. The class was easy, and required little work or effort beyond doing readings and showing up. Some readings were interesting, others few people bothered with. Class discussion didn't really ever move out of newspaper editorial territory. Hard to get an A, but a really easy B and probably impossible to fail.

I really don't know where this guy gets half of his irrational ideas but I want my money back.  This course was taught with a huge right-wing bias and does little to justify his claims.  He treated us like we were naive and failed to acknowledge our ideas.  A waste of my money, I could have just watched Fox News
This guy rocks.  He has his views but as long as you give him a good argument he's open to it.  I would definitely take another course with him again.

4hr lecture on war theory can get dry and boring. Discussions help make it interesting but mostly its just Brenda talking. Taking notes is really important here because it's all you'll have to study from (apart from the readings, of which there is a lot.) Marks kinda hard, and exams are rather tough. OK class overall.

Brenda is one of the best profs at SFU. Her lectures are very informativedense, but, if you take good notes you'll do great. She makes herself available for help during office hours, break, and after class. She even sends you outlines to study from before tests. She's a prof that I check to see if she has a course offering each semester! The best!
Best poli-sci prof at SFU. Very knowledgable. She cares about her students and wants them to do well/help in any way she can.
She's a great professor, one of the best at SFU!
Absolutely great!

Awesome teacher. Very knowledgeable and interested in the topic. One of the best profs I've had at SFU. Need to go to class and take lots of notes. She tells you what will be on the tests in a round about way. TAKE A CLASS WITH HER!
Awesome Prof.  Just do the readings.  If you have any trouble, she will clarify and explain everything for you.  She is super helpful and overall was just a great class.

Dr. Lyshaug wants to walk in the heart of darkness but is scared of what is actually there.  That said, she is a wonderful professor and I would highly recommend taking her course.  She lets rambling hippies take over the class too much.  But in this class, there are a lot of those.
Excellent lecture with clarity!Very helpful and lets students raise issues and questions. Too nice to cut off the students. :(

Tried to find any way possible to deduct 10% off every project. Criticized the class and openly mocked people frequently. Just honestly not a very nice guy. Whereas most profs seem to want students to succeed, Vllasi looks for ways to punish them and lower their marks. And this is coming from someone who got an A.
Honestly was a great Prof, definitely recommend it for anyone taking Pol courses and cares about his students.
Loved the class!!!  Pretty simple and basic Poli Sci structure.  Just go to lectures and do the readings and no reason you cannot get an A!
Good class.  Enjoyed the material.  She seems a bit new to teaching but overall the course was balanced and fairly straight forward.
Super nice, but can be tough
Awesome Prof! The Best.
I liked her, she is smart and knows her stuff. The people ducking out of class are clowns anyway so who cares what they or their loser friends think?

Sandra is the best prof in this often egotistical department. SFU is so lucky to get her from Dalhousie. Nice, approachable, and sympathetic. What more could you ask for? She is also brilliant, but open to alternative answers to complex issuees.
Very nice always willing to help
Cares a lot about his students, and is very approachable. Whether you're taking POL as your major or an elective, go with Rado.

Dimitrov is a great prof who displays genuine care for his student's success. He may initially come off as cold and having high expectations, but I believe this stems from his vast professional background. He makes criteria and expectations quite clear and gives students a roadmap for success. He is also quite funny and his lectures are engaging.

Worst prof ever!!! No empathy what so ever. Does not check emails rants about his experience doesn't even finish lecture. Poor class structure. Changes the syllabus based on feedback from few students yet when u speak to him about excruciating circumstances he does not accommodate even if the faculty is involvedExpects students to be available 24/7

This class has been a total boys club, men are always talking over the women, comes across as kinda misogynistic. Probably would be a better experience if you are a man. Not very personable. Seems like he isn't very interested in teaching. Also bro can't stop plugging his own website.

Not accommodating or caring to students with disabilities (refuses to even acknowledge it). All the life advice he gives in class are common sense and nothing sensational. His better-than-all attitude takes away from the diplomatic elements he tries to teach in class. Would not take again.

I took POL 349 with Professor Dimitrov. While he was a fantastic lecturer, I found that he was not very approachable. He is very smart in his field and his lectures are very interesting, though, so that somewhat makes up for it. Nevertheless, I will not take another course with him.

Dimitrov is the best professor I've had in my four years at SFU. This is the first time I have felt that a professor genuinely cares about the careers and the lives his students will have after his course. He has a wealth of experience working in diplomacy and international relations. The simulation was the most engaging in-class assessment method.

Prof. Dimitrov is one of the best and most memorable professors I've met. He is hilarious, eloquent, and knowledgeable; you'll definitely learn a lot from his lectures since they are concise yet insightful. Fair grading and workload. One thing to keep in mind is that active participation is important: read assigned articles, take notes, and engage.

Dr. Dimitrov truly cares about his students. All of the assessments were fair, and the simulation was particularly fun. He always includes anecdotes about his diplomatic experiences and that enhances the class tremendously. He assigns a lot of reading but it tends to be interesting and well-integrated in the lecture. I highly recommend him!

Dr. Dimitrov is my favourite prof at SFU! His lectures are engaging and his stories about his personal experience in the field are inspiring. The simulations he does in this class are captivating and teach you real-life skills. He grades fairly and the assignments are clearly outlined. I highly recommend taking a class with Dr. Dimitrov if you can!
Dr Dimitrov is the best professor I have so far at SFU. His lectures are engaging, he's incredibly knowledgeable, and he marks very fairly. He is also is very accessible outside of class time

Radoslav Dimitrov's first year POL 141 course provides a great introduction to world politics. He seems overqualified for this position, being able to go into great depth on topics concerning International Relations off the top of his head. Definitely attend the lecture and take notes there because they seemed to be more helpful than the textbook.

Professor Dimitrovs class has been my favourite so far at SFU. This class was graded by 4 assignments, which includes a simulation. The simulation (group project) seemed confusing at times, but was a very rewarding learning experience. The midterm was lecture based (but take notes of everything he says!). Kind and assessable outside of class.

I took his POL 340 class back in the fall semester. Not only is he hilarious, but he is also caring about his students. At first he may seem unapproachable, but I promise that he is. I would take his class again and I recommend others to take 340 or his other POL courses! He is a harder grader, but I find that I learn more that way.

Aaron Hoffman is unfit to be a professor. He is far too opinionated in his own views affecting his own teachings. He is also very unprofessional, unorganized, and quite honestly his style of teaching isn't really appropriate for the topics discussed. 
He will encourage you to raise your hand for questions or answers and cut you off mid sentence.

Surprised he went into academics, could have made it doing stand up comedy. Pretty solid prof overall, course material felt a bit thin at times but his feedback helped improve my writing for sure. Lectures felt like an oddly educational sitcom, tons of fun.

Hoffman is an awesome and funny lecturer as well as a really nice person. Although there were quite a few graded assignments that are quite tedious at times and only worth 5% of your grade, the course was rather interesting and engaging. If you put in the work you will definitely do well.

Dr. Munoz-Martinez is one of the best professors in the Political Science department.  Her knowledge of Latin America and well everything other region is quite impressive. She is a critical prof and pushes you to learn and challenge your own misconceptions.  She is very kind and a fair marker.  Show her respect and she will do the same for you!
Surprise she hasn't been fired.
Well the last class was a take home exam prep. Classes was meant for discussion time and not many read the readings. So classes were short

As we got deeper into the semester, lectures only got shorter and shorter and the last class was indeed 20 minutes or less. While at first it was nice getting to leave early, at a certain point it felt useless to come to class when it took way longer to get to campus than how long the lecture time was (esp when he just reads off 2/30 slides)

Logan is a terrible lecturer and incoherent. He tries freestyling the lecture off the top of his head but never ends up producing anything meaningful to say. attendance is mandatory but he cuts his lectures down to 20 mins and wastes everyones time. He is rude and uses a TM to grade everything despite this being an UD class. do not take his classes

Mandatory lectures only went for 20min, he would just skip through a couple slides when there's like 30 of them. He doesn't give proper explanations or reasoning on email. Used a TM to do his marking which should not happen for upper classes.
Excellent instructor. Clear guidelines. The assignment simulation exercise was lots of fun. Very engaging prof. Will take again.

I took pol346 with logan and this is my second class with him. He is by far my favourite prof at sfu. He is personable and doesnt expect much from his students. All you need to do is show up to class and you will do great. Pol 346 was on a pretty boring topic, but Logan did make many aspects of it interesting. GOATED prof
Great prof who rewards hard work--do your research. Very little leeway for late submissions or missed deadlines.
I have him for the fourth times now. i love his lecture and he tells you the general ideas what is going to be on the exam. perhaps, too much anti trump statements

Logan is amazing! He is the best professor in the political science department by far. His lectures were not only informative but really interesting. You will at least get an A- in this class if you pay attention to what he says. If you have him as your TA that is a bonus because he is a really fair marker.
Take this class only if you want to raise your GPA, he is easy since he is only here for the money. Haven't made faculty in years because that would require extra effort.
Horrible.  Should not be teaching.
Lacked enthusiasm for the course, didn't learn anything, waste of time
regret taking this course, poor lecturer and just bad!
Inability to show the least amount of interest in the course or students
seminar is great, but the lectures are hard to follow
HORROBLE!!

Caring and knowledgeable professor. A significant amount of material to read however videos are used to further understanding and can be interesting. The midterm was unreasonable and solely used to bring down the class average. Do not expect feedback on assignments. Lectures are interesting and the professor genuinely cares about the students

Terrible criteria for the assignments and has no care for the grading system when marking items. Extremely harsh when it comes to marking in general and the assignments do not need to be that long. His claim is 'write to fill the paper'?!
Awesome class!!!  Tough as nails though but well worth the effort!!!!

Ben's interest and passion is very evident in the subject of Security. He definitely has a very eclectic style of teaching. I thoroughly enjoyed his class and would definitely take another upper division course with him. I found him to be very personable and easy to approach. My grade for him is an A-. Take care Ben!

definitely a demanding prof - but i daresay that those people who don't like him don't have much to contribute to class anyways...he's a good professor - his job is not to babysit you, but rather to help you learn and critically think - i'd take him again without hesitation
In my opinion, the toughest prof currently in the SFU Poli Sci department.  Not a class for slackers.  You better think critically and there's no room for half ass remarks.
Might be a bit crazy, but amazing material and approach to teaching that is not common - particularly in SFU POLI. And yes, rather hot...

Admittedly, I'll say I have a man-crush.  But, oddly, I left the class depressed for the world every time.  I think Iran is going to explode upon itself real soon because of this man.  Love the class.
The guy is deep.  I like him
Be prepared to work hard.

I love Dr. Ayers!! She is the best professor I have ever had. I thought the course was going to be boring (Africa in the Global Political Economy) but Ayers helped shed light on why Africa is in such a mess.

She is definitely on the critical side. Great professor, she is one of the best in POL SCI at SFU. The course dealt with Africa in the GPE. The course lays bare the liberal IPE conception that economics is a positive sum game.
